channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Stats NZ advised risk 2023 census option would produce 'very poor quality data'
item.description: The government has picked one of the least favoured options for running the next census, and the funding, though boosted, has been criticised as inadequate.

item.title: Auckland mussel farm faces local opposition
item.description: Opponents of a proposal for a big mussel farm in Auckland's Hauraki gulf are worried the project will destroy the local sea environment.

item.title: Two on the run after police chase in Hamilton
item.description: Two people are on the run after a crash following a police pursuit in Hamilton this morning.

item.title: Land secured for new Central Otago airport
item.description: Tarras - a small farming settlement in Central Otago - is being eyed up as a possible location for a new airport.

item.title: Fewer babies born prematurely during lockdown - specialist
item.description: It appears fewer babies were born prematurely during the lockdown, putting New Zealand in line with a trend seen in other countries.

item.title: Former Blue Chip boss Bryers arrested in Australia for role in alleged major tax fraud
item.description: A disgraced New Zealand businessman has been arrested for involvement in an alleged major tax fraud in Australia.

item.title: Most want Napier City Council to use savings to plug $6m hole instead of rates hike
item.description: Eighty-eight percent of submitters to the council's annual plan say that will allow it to stick to its plan to increase rates by 4.8 percent while helping those struggling due to the pandemic.

item.title: Civil Defence makes 'good progress' on visiting cut-off Northland residents
item.description: Civil Defence has made contact with residents in difficult to reach remote districts cut off by the flooding in Northland.

item.title: Severe gale warnings in place across North Island regions
item.description: A strong wind warning is in place for Auckland, Coromandel, coastal parts of Waikato, Northland, south of Napier, and the Tararua district.

item.title: Police recover body from car submerged in Ruahini Canal
item.description: Police have recovered a body from Ruahini Canal in the Bay of Plenty after a car plunged into the water.

item.title: Isolation facilities: 'We are now close to exhausting our nationwide capacity' - Megan Woods
item.description: The minister in charge of managed isolation facilities, Megan Woods, says New Zealand is close to exhausting its nationwide capacity at isolation facilities.

item.title: Covid-19 border restrictions leave Korean boy stranded in NZ and unable to go to school
item.description: A six-year-old Korean boy has not been able to attend school for months because Covid-19 border restrictions have left him without a legal guardian in the country.

item.title: South Auckland losing its trees while northern suburbs get more
item.description: An Auckland Council report has found that while there is a small increase in overall tree cover across the region, some parts of the city have lost significant canopy cover.

item.title: Home detention for selling caged eggs as free range
item.description: An Auckland man has been sentenced to 12 months home detention for selling millions of eggs from caged hens as free range.

item.title: Defence lawyers call for urgent review of Covid-19 prosecutions
item.description: Defence lawyers are worried the already backlogged district courts will be overwhelmed if police pursue all Covid-19 prosecutions.

item.title: New Plymouth councillor prepared to fight against Māori ward proposal
item.description: A controversial New Plymouth councillor says he will spearhead a citizens-initiated referendum against the formation of a Māori ward in the city if no one else steps up to the plate.

item.title: Kuia attacked at BP in Christchurch: 'It's ruined my life'
item.description: A kuia who was attacked while working at a BP station in Christchurch still finds it hard to leave the safety of her house, two months after the violent incident.

item.title: Marlborough's plan to honour its mighty Wairau River
item.description: The banks along Marlborough's Wairau River are set to be transformed into a regional park, to honour the river as a taonga for Māori, while securing its future as a major regional resource.
